title: Różanystok
text:
Różanystok is a <a href="village">village</a> and former <a href="monastery">monastery</a> in northeastern <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, known regionally for both its ornate 18th-century minor <a href="basilica">basilica</a> and its agricultural <a href="magnet%20school">magnet school</a>. It lies approximately south-east of <a href="D%C4%85browa%20Bia%C5%82ostocka">Dąbrowa Białostocka</a>, north of <a href="Sok%C3%B3%C5%82ka">Sokółka</a>, and north of the regional capital <a href="Bia%C5%82ystok">Białystok</a>.
Geography.
Różanystok, formerly known as Krzywy Stok ("Crooked Slope"), is located in the township of <a href="D%C4%85browa%20Bia%C5%82ostocka">Dąbrowa Białostocka</a>, which is in turn situated in the <a href="Podlaskie">Podlaskie</a> region's <a href="Sok%C3%B3%C5%82ka%20County">Sokółka County</a> division. From the years 1975-1998 the area was part of the <a href="Bia%C5%82ystok%20Voivodeship%20%281975-1998%29">Białystok Voivodeship (1975-1998)</a> administrative district. The <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a>ian <a href="city">city</a> of <a href="Grodno">Grodno</a> can be seen from the Basilica's bell tower.
Part of the village's geographical <a href="Border">boundary</a> is defined by a stone wall that remains from its days as a monastery.
Różanystok is a stop on the northeastern Poland <a href="Polskie%20Koleje%20Pa%C5%84stwowe">PKP</a> train line, which also stops in <a href="Bia%C5%82ystok">Białystok</a>, <a href="Sok%C3%B3%C5%82ka">Sokółka</a>, <a href="August%C3%B3w">Augustów</a> and <a href="Suwa%C5%82ki">Suwałki</a>.
History.
The village is home to a well-known Mary, Mother of God <a href="shrine">shrine</a>, to which tens of thousands of <a href="pilgrim">pilgrim</a>s travel each year. The shrine's focus is a 17th-century image of <a href="Blessed%20Virgin%20Mary">Mary</a> holding the infant <a href="Jesus">Jesus</a> which is believed to be miraculous. A "coronation" celebration for the Różanystok icon was held on June 28, 1981, and the church was named a minor basilica on August 30, 1987.<a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20070217204834/http%3A//www.rozanystok.pl/historia/%3Fgo%3Drys"></a>
Since 1954, Różanystok has also been the location of a state-run "Zespól Szkól Rolniczych" (Group Agricultural School). The school's five-year technical program prepares students for work in <a href="agriculture">agriculture</a> and related fields, while its four-year <a href="economics">economics</a> program prepares students for work in business and/or advanced studies at the university level.
The church complex was used as a military storage depot during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, and several of its buildings were destroyed in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.<a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20070217204834/http%3A//www.rozanystok.pl/historia/%3Fgo%3Drys"></a>
Demographics.
Most of Różanystok's 510 residents, who primarily live in two three-story apartment buildings within the village, attend, work at, or are retired from employment at the school.
